questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common malignancy of the GI tract?
questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. Tumors in the proximal colon often grow as polypoid, exophytic masses. These tumors rarely 
cause obstruction. Carcinomas of the distal colon tend to be annular lesions that produce napkin-ring constrictions 
and luminal narrowing.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy?

options.d: A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps

questions.explanation:
Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy. Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecture 
throughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lack 
cytological features of dysplasia.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in patients with juvenile polyps?
questions.explanation:
1053 
Sold by @itachibot The most common site of juvenile polyps is in the rectum. Juvenile polyps are focal malformations of the epithelium and lamina propria. They may be 
sporadic or syndromic. They typically present with rectal bleeding in children < 5 years. • Sporadic juvenile polyps - solitary lesions, also called retention polyps • Juvenile polyposis - autosomal dominant syndrome with multiple hamartomatous polyps that 
have malignant potential

questions.question:
Question 4: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and 
painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is 
the most likely diagnosis? 1049 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated 
crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp. 1054 
Sold by @itachibot Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the 
rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal 
bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass. The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. • Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp. • Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be 
premalignant. Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable. • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces. • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory 
debris. Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the 
lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.

questions.question:
Question 5: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectal 
cancer?
questions.explanation:
Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectal 
cancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of 
30 years.

questions.question:
Question 6: What is the minimum number of polyps necessary for the diagnosis of familial adenomatous 
polyposis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires 100 polyps. The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of 
the below: • Germline mutation in APC gene • 100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition) • Any colorectal adenomas < 30 years in a patient with a family history of FAP • Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts 
in a patient with a family history of FAP Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age of 30 
years and nearly always by age of 50 years. Attenuated FAP is a less severe form of FAP with the following features: • Usually <100 adenomas • First appear usually in late childhood • Adenomas usually 1 cm until adulthood • Adenomas fewer and later 1055 
Sold by @itachibot • Adenomas and carcinomas 60–75% right-sided • The mean age of carcinoma is 55 years The following image shows a gross specimen of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

questions.question:
Question 7: Indirect ophthalmoscopy of an infant revealed congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment 
epithelium. This is seen as an extraintestinal manifestation in association with which of the 
following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Classic FAP and Gardner's syndrome are associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium 
(RPE) hypertrophy. Congenital hypertrophy of the RPE can be generally detected at birth and is, therefore, an adjunct 
to the early screening of FAP.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?

options.a: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
options.b: Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
options.c: There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
options.d: It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11

questions.explanation:
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome. It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene 
STK11. It is characterized by: • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation • Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine 
cancer) Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by 
annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter. 1056 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair 
loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On 
endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a 
diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome. It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years. Clinical features include: • Diarrhea and abdominal pain • Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation • Cachexia and anemia • Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due to 
abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following acts as the initiating mutation in the majority of sporadic colon 
cancers? 1051 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The majority of sporadic colon tumors typically include loss of function mutation of 
APC gene, early in the neoplastic process (the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence). About 10-15% of sporadic colon cancers involve the microsatellite instability pathway, which is 
associated with DNA mismatch repair defects (Lynch syndrome).

questions.question:
Question 11: A 70-year-old man with hematochezia and weight loss is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. 
Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The two most important prognostic factors of colorectal cancer are the depth of invasion and the 
presence of lymph node metastases. The liver is the most common site of metastasis from the colon due to its portal drainage.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 52-year-old lady has just been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. On taking history, 
she revealed that both her mother and her elder sister had been diagnosed with synchronous 
colorectal and endometrial cancer in their forties. She should be tested for mutations in 
which of the following genes?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch 
syndrome. She should be tested for mutations in MSH genes. It occurs due to defective DNA mismatch repair. It is caused by inherited mutations in genes that 
encode proteins responsible for the detection, excision, and repair of errors that occur during 
DNA replication. They include MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 or EPCAM genes. It is the most common syndromic cause of colon cancer. It tends to occur at younger ages than 
sporadic colon cancers and often involves the right colon. Familial clustering of cancers occurs at 
several sites including: • Colorectum, small bowel, and stomach • Endometrium and ovary 1057 
Sold by @itachibot • Ureters • Brain • Hepatobiliary tract and pancreas • Skin

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is incorrect about tumors of the appendix?

options.d: Type 2 cells are involved in gaseous exchange

questions.explanation:
Primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix is usually of mucinous type. Peritoneal dissemination of mucinous tumors can cause pseudomyxoma peritonei. The most common tumor of the appendix is carcinoid tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost 
always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix. 
Goblet cell variant of carcinoid tumor is more aggressive. 1058 
Sold by @itachibot Congenital anomalies, ARDS, Infections
